properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for Monday afternoon into Tuesday morning. Snow will begin Monday afternoon and continue into early Tuesday morning. Total snowfall amounts near 10 cm are possible. Travel will be impacted due to accumulating snow, particularly during the Monday afternoon and Tuesday morning commutes. This snowfall is due to a developing low pressure system which will track south of the lower Great Lakes on Monday. There remains some uncertainty regarding the track of the low, and the expected snowfall amounts. Environment Canada will continue to monitor the situation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-11T12:14:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-10T20:15:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0578698839.2019
Area: Gatineau, Belleville - Quinte West - Eastern Northumberland County, Cobourg - Colborne - Western Northumberland County, Tamworth - Sydenham - South Frontenac, Stirling - Tweed - Madoc, Kingston - Odessa - Frontenac Islands, Napanee - Consecon, Picton - Sandbanks Park, Westport - Charleston Lake, Lindsay - Southern Kawartha Lakes, Peterborough City - Lakefield - Southern Peterborough County, Prescott and Russell, Smiths Falls - Perth - Eastern Lanark County, Plevna - Sharbot Lake - Western Lanark County, Ottawa North - Kanata - Orléans, Ottawa South - Richmond - Metcalfe

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for Monday into Monday night. Snow will begin early Monday morning and continue through the evening. Snowfall accumulations of 10 to 15 cm are possible by the time the snow ends late Monday night. Travel will be impacted Monday due to accumulating snow, particularly during the afternoon commute. This snowfall is due to a developing low pressure system which will track south of the lower Great Lakes on Monday. There remains some uncertainty regarding the track of the low, and the expected snowfall amounts. Environment Canada will continue to monitor the situation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-11T12:13:24-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall beginning Monday afternoon into Tuesday morning. Snow will move into the region Monday afternoon with snowfall accumulations near 15 cm expected by Tuesday morning. Travel will be impacted Monday afternoon into Tuesday morning due to the accumulating snow. This snowfall is due to a developing low pressure system which will track south of the lower Great Lakes on Monday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-11T12:16:24-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Favourable conditions for freezing rain will develop early afternoon on Monday over the Lakes District and Stuart-Nechako region. Freezing rain will create icy surfaces and these conditions may last into the evening hours. The freezing rain will abate as surface temperatures rise above zero and the precipitation moves out of the area. As the event unfolds, further public forecast regions may be added to the warning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-11T15:55:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-10T23:56:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3111729974.2019
Area: Lakes District, Stuart - Nechako
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and wind expected for midweek. Total snowfall: 15 cm with the potential for higher amounts. Maximum wind gusts: up to 100 km/h along the coast. Locations: Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River, and along the north coast from Makkovik to Nain. Time span: Tuesday night to early Thursday. Remarks: Snowfall is forecast to begin Tuesday night and continue into Thursday. Late on Wednesday, strong winds are expected to develop along the coast. Visibilities could be reduced in snow and blowing snow and warnings may be issued. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-11T12:21:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-10T20:22:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1887583515.2019
Area: Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity, Nain and vicinity, Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Arctic air entrenched in the central interior combined with a Pacific warm front delivering warm moist air aloft will produce a wintry mix on Monday and Tuesday. Freezing rain or ice pellets will develop over the Prince George, Cariboo, Chilcotin and 100 Mile regions Monday evening and last through to Tuesday morning. Freezing rain and ice pellets are forecast to change to rain or showers on Tuesday as the warm air reaches the surface and brings the temperature above zero. Over the Bulkley Valley region including Smithers, snow or ice pellets will develop near midday Monday. The potential for freezing rain will depend on the position of the warm front and the strength of the warm air aloft. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-11T15:59:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-11T00:00:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0632909558.2019
Area: Chilcotin, Cariboo - north including Quesnel, Cariboo - south including Williams Lake, 100 Mile, Bulkley Valley, Prince George
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Update: High Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued For The Lakes Within Whiteshell Provincial Park
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the lakes within the Whiteshell Provincial Park area due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as levels as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing water or waters of unknown depth. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-11-11T17:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-11-10T17:17:06-06:00, 625A24BE-1F70-F9BA-5177-FF352049B289
Area: Whiteshell Provincial Park
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A snowfall to start the week. A low pressure system over the Northeastern United States will bring snow over Southern Quebec late in the afternoon on Monday. The snow will intensify in the evening and persist during the day Tuesday, reaching Eastern Quebec. The morning commute will be particularly difficult Tuesday morning. Snowfall amounts of approximately 15 centimetres are expected over Southern and Central Quebec but could exceed 15 centimetres in the Eastern Townships, Beauce and Eastern Quebec. The snow will be accompanied by strong winds over Central and Eastern Quebec and give reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Be prepared for hazardous driving conditions because of reduced visibilities. The public is advised to monitor future forecasts for more information as the low pressure system's track becomes more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-11T06:12:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-10T14:13:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2703725598.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall possible on Monday. A developing low pressure system will track south of the Lower Great Lakes and will bring snow to eastern Ontario Monday. Snow is expected to begin Monday afternoon and continue into Monday night before ending Tuesday morning. Snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are possible by Tuesday morning. There is still considerable uncertainty with regards to the track of this system. Travel may be impacted Monday evening due to snow accumulation on the road. Environment Canada will continue to monitor the situation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for Monday into Monday night. Snow will begin early Monday morning and continue through the evening. Snowfall accumulations of 10 to 15 cm are possible by the time the snow ends late Monday night. Additionally, snow squalls may move into the Sarnia to Kettle Point areas early Tuesday morning and persist through the day. Local snowfall amounts near 15 cm are possible on Tuesday. Travel will be impacted Monday due to accumulating snow, particularly during the afternoon commute. This snowfall is due to a developing low pressure system which will track south of the lower Great Lakes on Monday. There remains some uncertainty regarding the track of the low, and the expected snowfall amounts. Environment Canada will continue to monitor the situation. A snow squall watch or warning may be issued as the event draws near. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Prolonged period of rainfall expected this week. Rainfall amounts: 50 to 70 mm. Potential for locally higher amounts. Locations: Southern and western Newfoundland. Time span: Tuesday morning to late Wednesday. Remarks: Snow is expected to transition to rain Tuesday afternoon and become heavy at times Tuesday night into Wednesday. Rainfall amounts are generally expected to be in the 50 to 70 mm range, but locally higher amounts are possible, especially along the south coast from Channel-Port aux Basques to the Burgeo-Ramea area. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-11T12:09:26-00:00

Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Bay St. George
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A strong low pressure system over Davis Strait will continue to spread heavy snowfall to portions of Baffin Island through the rest of the weekend, continuing until Monday. Total snowfall amounts near 25 cm can be expected in or around Qikiqtarjuaq. In addition, gusty northerly winds will combine with the falling snow, creating poor visibilities in snow and blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-11T07:35:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-10T15:36:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2189859155.2019
Area: Qikiqtarjuaq

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A snowfall to start the week. A low pressure system over the Northeastern United States will bring snow over Southern Quebec late Monday afternoon. The snow will intensify in the evening and persist during the day on Tuesday, reaching Eastern Quebec. The morning commute will be particularly difficult Tuesday morning. 15 to 20 centimetres of snow is expected over Southern and Central Quebec, and possibly more over Eastern Quebec. The snow will be accompanied by strong winds over Central and Eastern Quebec, reducing visibilities in blowing snow. Accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Hazardous driving conditions can be expected due to reduced visibilities. Please monitor future forecasts for more information as the low pressure system's track becomes more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Ice build-up due to freezing rain is expected or occurring. A strong northeasterly outflow has set up through the valleys and inlets in the north coast - inland regions which is acting to bring temperatures below the freezing mark overnight. A Pacific frontal system is slated to come onshore early Monday morning. The combination of warm air from the approaching system overriding the cold outflow will produce freezing rain in the Terrace and Kitimat regions starting mid to late Monday morning. Freezing rain will persist until Tuesday morning when the outflow weakens and temperatures rise above zero. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-11T15:53:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-10T23:54:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1742696315.2019
Area: North Coast - inland including Terrace, North Coast - inland including Kitimat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Conditions have deteriorated further than expected in Arviat, and a blizzard warning has been issued for the community. Winds should diminish sharply late this evening ending the blizzard. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-11T08:04:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-11T01:08:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1944554339.2019
Area: Arviat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Significant snowfall on Monday into Monday night. Snow will move into the region early Monday morning with all areas likely to receive accumulations of 15 cm by late Monday night. Gusty northeast winds off of Lake Ontario combined with the higher terrain of the Niagara Escarpment will lead to snowfall enhancement locally from near Hamilton eastward across northern Niagara. These areas could see snowfall amounts near 25 cm by late Monday night. Travel will be impacted Monday due to accumulating snow as well as locally reduced visibility in blowing snow. This snowfall is due to a developing low pressure system which will track south of the lower Great Lakes on Monday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-11T12:15:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-10T20:16:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0330397851.2019
Area: Dunnville - Caledonia - Haldimand, City of Hamilton, Burlington - Oakville, St. Catharines - Grimsby - Northern Niagara Region, Niagara Falls - Welland - Southern Niagara Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Approaching storm to give mixed precipitation Tuesday and Tuesday night. A developing low pressure system will affect Prince Edward Island beginning Monday night. Precipitation will begin as snow overnight and change to rain on Tuesday morning. Currently 5 to 10 centimetres of snowfall is forecast before the changeover to rain Tuesday morning. Indications are that rainfall amounts on Tuesday could be near 20 millimetres. The travelling public are urged to prepare for potentially difficult driving conditions for areas impacted by snow, as well as for areas with mixed precipitation Tuesday morning. Additional information will be provided as the details become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Approaching storm to bring snow, freezing rain and rain to the province Tuesday and Tuesday night. A developing low pressure system will affect New Brunswick beginning Monday night, starting as snow and then transitioning to rain in the south on Tuesday morning. For southern New Brunswick, near 10 centimetres of snowfall is expected before the changeover to rain. Over northern New Brunswick, precipitation is expected to remain as snow, where amounts in excess of 15 centimetres are likely before tapering to flurries Tuesday night. There is a high probability that snowfall warnings will be required for northern New Brunswick with the Monday morning forecast issue. In addition, there is the potential for an extended period of freezing rain Tuesday morning over southwestern parts of the province prior to changing to rain. The travelling public are urged to prepare for potentially difficult driving conditions for areas impacted by snow and mixed precipitation on Tuesday. Additional information will be provided as the details become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-11T11:52:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-10T19:53:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2569373343.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Approaching storm to bring significant rainfall Tuesday into Wednesday morning. A developing system will affect Nova Scotia beginning late Monday night or early Tuesday. Over northern areas of the province, precipitation will likely begin as a period of snow before changing to rain. Snowfall amounts are forecast to be 5 centimetres or less before the changeover. Over southern areas, precipitation is forecast to begin as rain. Indications are that rainfall amounts could reach or exceed 50 millimetres over some areas before changing to flurries Wednesday morning. Additional information will be provided as the details become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-11T11:45:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-10T19:46:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2635943211.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A snowfall to start the week. A low pressure system over the Northeastern United States will bring a heavy snowfall to start the week. Snow will reach Eastern Quebec Monday evening and intensify during the day on Tuesday. Precipitation will continue through Wednesday. Snowfall amounts of 20 to 30 centimetres are expected over the Lower St Lawrence, Gaspé Peninsula and North Shore areas. The snow will be accompanied by strong winds and will give reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Hazardous driving conditions can be expected due to reduced visibilities. Please monitor future forecasts for more information as the low pressure system's track becomes more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-11T12:40:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-10T20:41:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3306863060.2019
